channel.description: Recent content in Usage on resticprofile

item.title: Version
item.description: The version command displays resticprofile version. If run in vebose mode (using --verbose flag) additional information such as OS version or golang version or modules are displayed as well. $ resticprofile --verbose version

item.title: Generate a Keyfile
item.description: Generating random keys resticprofile has a handy tool to generate cryptographically secure random keys encoded in base64. You can simply put this key into a file and use it as a strong key for restic. On Linux and FreeBSD, the generator uses getrandom(2) if available, /dev/urandom otherwise. On OpenBSD, the generator uses getentropy(2). On other Unix-like systems, the generator reads from /dev/urandom. On Windows systems, the generator uses the CryptGenRandom API.

item.title: Memory
item.description: Minimum memory required restic can be memory hungry. I’m running a few servers with no swap and I managed to kill some of them during a backup. For that matter I’ve introduced a parameter in the global section called min-memory. The default value is 100MB. You can disable it by using a value of 0. It compares against (total - used) which is probably the best way to know how much memory is available (that is including the memory used for disk buffers/cache).

item.title: Locks
item.description: restic is already using a lock to avoid running some operations at the same time. Since resticprofile can run several commands in a profile, it could be better to run the whole batch in a lock so nobody can interfere in the meantime. For this to happen you can specify a lock file in each profile: toml yaml hcl json [src] lock = "/tmp/resticprofile-profile-src.lock" [src.backup] check-before = true exclude = [ "/**/.
